messages.text:
Hi, there's a cool discussion here: <https://julialang.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/240884-soss.2Ejl/topic/MTK.2C.20Soss.2C.20Catlab.3A.20Partially.20Symbolic.20Computing>

About the symbolic/DSL ecosystem  (modeling toolkit, soss etc) and where gen can fit in (genify vs MTK tracing, GFI and sampling for MTK problems etc)

We ask anyone joining to adhere to the Julia Code of Conduct. | To learn more about Julia, check out <https://julialang.org/>, or just come ask us here! | You can reach out to the admins of this Zulip by sending a direct message to @zulip-admins.

elements.text: Hi, there's a cool discussion here:
About the symbolic/DSL ecosystem  (modeling toolkit, soss etc) and where gen can fit in (genify vs MTK tracing, GFI and sampling for MTK problems etc)

messages.text: Hi everyone, I’m not sure if this is the correct place to ask questions. But I’m wondering why Gen doesn’t have a built-in NUTS sampler similar to those provided by Turing or Pyro.

messages.text: does gen have anything for continuous bayesian learning <https://discourse.julialang.org/t/recursive-bayes/55036/2>

attachments.title: Recursive Bayes
attachments.text: It’s funny, this is such a standard use of Bayesian analysis, but most PPLs don’t have much support for it. It’s usually better to do inference for as much data as you have at a time, because the posterior is represented as a function of the data. There are two main exceptions to this: If you make strong assumptions about the data, e.g. for a Kalman filter you assume normality. If you make very few assumptions, and do things very empirically. Then you end up with a particle filter. One big fo...
